newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa trims gains, sterling rises again.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa trims gains, sterling rises again.

text.p: LIFFE cocoa futures trimmed some gains to end Wednesday midsession higher but near session's floor after early buying dried up, traders said.
The market came under pressure towards the close from buoyant sterling. The British unit eclipsed Tuesday's six-year high to reach a fresh peak at 2.9760 marks.
The sterling denominated futures had a sluggish start but the momentum soon picked up as light buying re-emerged.
Benchmark September was driven to a high of 1,053 stg a tonne but ended just three stg up at 1,046.
Despite the late pull-back, traders said the market's outlook remained constructive.
Overall, the market did well on Tuesday despite soaring sterling.
Immediately, the market could easily breach its minor target at 1,060 before attempting to conquer the next barrier at the 1,087-1,108 chart gap basis September.
Support is seen intact at 1,000, the lows seen last week after the blistering rally that pushed values to one-year peak of 1,170 stg a few days earlier.
Since then, the market had been struggling to return to the 1,060 area and ultimately the key 1,100 resistance.
But traders said recent volatility was purely technical and had not altered the positive fundamental picture.

Broker GNI said overnight news from Abidjan which put Ivorian cocoa arrivals at 1.05-1.06 million tonnes up to July 4 against 1.148 million last year could be viewed by some as a sign of lower supply.
"But this ignores the fact that virtually no mid-crop cocoa has yet been delivered," it said in a commentary.
